item.title: Tear Gas Clears Path for Trump to Visit Church
item.description: Police officers used flash grenades to disperse a crowd so the president could visit for a photo opportunity. And in New York, protesters and looters defied a curfew.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the White House, where President Trump called violent demonstrations in American cities “domestic terrorism.”

item.title: How Minneapolis, One of America’s Most Liberal Cities, Struggles With Racism
item.description: The Midwestern city that has been the site of unrest views itself as embracing multiculturalism. But it also struggles with segregation and racial gaps on education.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers helped clear water on Saturday after a Wells Fargo bank was destroyed the night before during protests in Minneapolis.

item.title: As Coronavirus Toll Preoccupies U.S., Rivals Test Limits of American Power
item.description: The coronavirus may have changed almost everything, but it didn’t change this: Global competition spins ahead — and in many ways has accelerated.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Australia Department Of Defence, via Reuters
item.media:description: The amphibious assault ship America conducted maneuvers with other Australian and U.S. Navy vessels in the South China Sea in April, one of four such operations this year.

item.title: Is America’s Pandemic Waning or Raging? Yes
item.description: A single day reveals divergent realities across the country: As cases drop in the Northeast and some cities reopen, other places report stubbornly high numbers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chicago has been shuttered since March, with little hope that life in America’s third-largest city will return to normal soon.

item.title: How Protests Have Changed Since the Rodney King Riots
item.description: Wednesday: Although the parallels with the Rodney King riots are clear, a lot has changed.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters blocked the intersection of Figueroa and Olympic in downtown Los Angeles on Friday.

item.title: Hey @jack, You Should Also Look at These Tweets From @realdonaldtrump
item.description: We analyzed the president’s Twitter feed for a week. A third of his posts contained falsehoods or murky accusations, underscoring the challenge to Twitter’s chief, Jack Dorsey, of policing him.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Pandemic Could Scar a Generation of Working Mothers
item.description: Working from home has highlighted and compounded the heavier domestic burden borne by women. Now office reopenings may force new career sacrifices.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Da'Shaunae Marisa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Virgina Dressler spends her days at home caring for her 3-year-old twins while managing a career as a digital librarian.

item.title: Steve King Sinks in Iowa
item.description: Protesters went back to the streets and, oh, elections took place: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: When Jail Becomes Normal
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: The exercise yard at California Medical Facility in Vacaville, Calif.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Germany Will Lift E.U. Travel Ban
item.description: Epidemiologists said protests around the United States would almost certainly lead to more cases. Republicans are seeking a new city to host their convention. The premier American health agency failed on several fronts to keep up with the pandemic, a Times investigation finds.
item.media:credit: Christof Stache/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An airport terminal in Munich in May. Germany imposed travel restrictions in mid-March.

item.title: Live Updates on George Floyd Protests: Latest News and Video
item.description: The eighth day of protests was largely peaceful, with only sporadic reports of looting overnight. Washington is becoming a heavily armed fortress, and criticism of President Trump’s response is mounting.
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times

item.title: The Journalism Students Helping The Times Cover California
item.description: A collaboration between the National desk and the University of California-Berkeley offered a chance at “public service work during this unparalleled time.”
item.dc:creator: John Otis
item.media:credit: Casey Smith
item.media:description: Katey Rusch reported on shelter-in-place enforcement in Santa Clara County.

item.title: In Los Angeles, the Ghosts of Rodney King and Watts Rise Again
item.description: Los Angeles has been one of America’s reference points for racial unrest. This time protesters are bringing their anger to the people they say need to hear it most: the white and wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned police cruiser burned after being set on fire during protests on Beverly Boulevard in west Los Angeles, on Saturday.

item.title: Rod Rosenstein, Key Figure in Russia Inquiry, Defends Mueller Appointment
item.description: A year after he stepped down as deputy attorney general and nearly two after his last oversight hearing, Republican senators called Mr. Rosenstein to testify about the investigation.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Katie Benner and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The former deputy attorney general Rod J. Rosenstein.

item.title: A World War II Flag Taken During a Reno Protest is Returned
item.description: The U.S.S. Reno flag was anonymously returned with a note that said it “needed protecting.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Kenzie Margiott, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A flag from a World War II battleship was anonymously returned to a reporter in Reno, Nev., on Tuesday.

item.title: Teresa Leger Fernandez Beats Valerie Plame in New Mexico House Primary
item.description: Ms. Leger Fernandez, a progressive who emphasized her long history in the district, overcame a well-funded challenge from Ms. Plame and defeated several other Democratic rivals.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Ramsay de Give for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teresa Leger Fernandez in Taos Pueblo, N.M., after meeting with Pueblo leaders in January. She received endorsements from high-profile Democrats including Senator Elizabeth Warren and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

item.title: Ella Jones Is Elected First Black Mayor of Ferguson
item.description: Ms. Jones is also the first woman to lead the Missouri city, which erupted in protests in 2014 after a white police officer shot and killed Michael Brown, a black teenager.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: David Carson/St. Louis Post-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ella Jones, a Ferguson, Mo., city councilwoman, in 2017. She was elected mayor on Tuesday night.

item.title: Steve King, House Republican With a History of Racist Remarks, Loses Primary
item.description: Mr. King, one of the nation’s most divisive elected officials, saw his power in Congress curtailed last year after he questioned why white supremacy was considered offensive.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Steve King of Iowa has long made racist remarks about immigrants, and Republicans had worried before the primary election on Tuesday that he was an electoral liability.

item.title: How Trump’s Idea for a Photo Op Led to Havoc in a Park
item.description: When the history of the Trump presidency is written, the clash with protesters that preceded President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square may be remembered as one of its defining moments.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman, Katie Rogers, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Katie Benner, Haley Willis, Christiaan Triebert and David Botti
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Police advance on protesters outside the White House to clear a path for President Trump to walk to St. Johns church in Washington on Monday

item.title: For Police Officers, Demonstrations Take a Toll and Test Duty
item.description: As the world watches demonstrations unfold on television and social media, both the best and the worst of American law enforcement has been on display.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fireworks thrown by protesters erupt behind officers outside the Police Department in Ferguson, Mo., on Sunday.

item.title: The Great Instagram Blackout
item.description: We have mixed feelings about #BlackoutTuesday, too.

item.title: Holding It Aloft, He Incited a Backlash. What Does the Bible Mean to Trump?
item.description: The president has a long history of contradictory remarks about the book he held up after forcibly clearing protesters for a photo op on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s visit to St. John’s Episcopal Church on Monday has drawn criticism.

item.title: Trump Deploys the Full Might of Federal Law Enforcement to Crush Protests
item.description: Nearly a dozen federal agencies — even the Transportation Security Administration — were sent to Washington and other cities after the president vowed to “dominate” protesters.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Law enforcement advanced on protests outside the White House on Monday. Local officials say the federal response has gone beyond acceptable.

item.title: 15 West Point Cadets Test Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: More than 1,100 cadets returned to campus ahead of President Trump’s commencement speech in mid-June.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Julius Motal/Associated Press
item.media:description: Cadets during graduation ceremonies at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y., last year.

item.title: March Peacefully or ‘Take the Streets’? Protesters Debate What Comes Next
item.description: What began as a protest over one man’s death in police custody in Minneapolis has grown into a nationwide movement with diverse activists, tactics and demands.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Caitlin Dickerson
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstrator raised his hands while trying to keep the peace between the Louisville Metro Police and people who were throwing water bottles at law enforcement on Monday in downtown Louisville, Ky.

item.title: In Rare Break, Some Republicans Reject Trump’s Harsh Response to Unrest
item.description: The president’s crackdown on peaceful protesters drew condemnations from a handful of Republican lawmakers, but Democrats planned to push them to back up their words with legislative measures.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, condemned President Trump’s photo opportunity.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Reflecting on six months with the virus.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Geofencing at the Ballot Box
item.description: Groups trying to get voters to sign up for mail-in ballots in November had a big opportunity in Tuesday’s primary elections.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Trump’s Visits to Church and Shrine Draw Fierce Rebukes From D.C. Clergy
item.description: The Episcopal bishop Mariann Edgar Budde and the Catholic Archbishop Wilton Gregory said the president was using holy sites as political props.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Elizabeth Dias
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, at the Saint John Paul II National Shrine in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Primary Elections Happen Against Backdrop of Protests, Police and a Pandemic
item.description: A day of disrupted voting across the country produced a notable result in Iowa, where Steve King, who was ostracized after he questioned why white supremacy was offensive, was denied a 10th term.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voter registering to cast her ballot at the Seafarer's Union Hall polling station in Philadelphia.

item.title: College Board Scraps Plans for SAT at Home
item.description: The organization that oversees the standardized test used for college admissions said the technology requirements for taking it remotely would be too great for some students.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: A student preparing for the SAT. The organization that administers the exam had to cancel dates for millions of students this spring during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Senate Confirms Inspector General to Oversee Virus Bailout Funds
item.description: Brian D. Miller, the White House lawyer tapped to oversee the Treasury Department’s $500 billion fund, has said he would not be influenced by political pressure.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Leah Millis/Reuters
item.media:description: Brian D. Miller this month at the Capitol. He will be required to monitor the flow of pandemic recovery funds and report any wrongdoing to Congress.

item.title: A Latter-Day Rip Van Winkle Emerges, Blinking, Into a Surreal Reality
item.description: Daniel Thorson went into a silent retreat in mid-March, meditating through 75 coronavirus news cycles, Boris Johnson’s hospitalization, social distancing and sourdough starter. Now he’s catching up.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Jacob Hannah for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daniel Thorson outside the cabin where he just finished a 75-day silent meditation retreat at the Monastic Academy in Lowell, Vt.

item.title: Was That a Firecracker or a Gunshot? Unpredictability on America’s Streets
item.description: Hundreds of confrontations are playing out between protesters and police officers nationwide, some devolving into violence in a finger snap.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters knelt before a line of officers in Ferguson, Mo., on Sunday.

item.title: Mary J. Wilson, Barrier-Smashing Zookeeper, Dies at 83
item.description: Ms. Wilson, who had the coronavirus, was the first African-American senior zookeeper at what is now the Maryland Zoo in Baltimore.
item.dc:creator: John Leland

item.title: Trump's Bible Photo: What Democracy Scholars Thought
item.description: The president’s true believers saw a message to appreciate. Many others saw something more alarming.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The authorities used riot-control tactics to disrupt peaceful protests outside the White House to clear a path for President Trump’s walk to St. John’s Church in Washington on Monday night.

item.title: ‘He Could Have Been My Brother’: Women’s Voices in the Protests
item.description: A city that lay quiet for two months is now pulsing with protesters. Here are their stories.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg

item.title: Republican Convention Feud Escalates as Officials Weigh New Site
item.description: After a stalemate with Democrats in North Carolina, Republicans said the president wouldn’t accept the party’s nomination at its convention in Charlotte, as planned, but would do so in another city.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Republican National Convention was held in Cleveland in 2016.
